utterances: Inpatient can cost tens of thousands of dollars for a 90-day treatment period.
Outpatient can be 60, $70 per hour and we're talking about expenses for traditional therapy that are 10 to a hundredfold more than this model.
Those other treatments, honestly, are not much more effective.
The effectiveness rates for PROP and other drug treatment and counseling methods, says Klausner, are comparable.
About a third of the participants become clean by the end of the three-month program.
Klausner says vouchers can also help people sober up enough to receive additional treatment and recovery services if needed.
PROP staff are currently talking with potential partners about expanding the program in California.
For NPR News, I'm Shia Levitt in San Francisco.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
More in a moment on DAY TO DAY.
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Liane Hansen.
On Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics will release its report on job openings.
And if it's anything like other U.S.
Labor Department reports in the last few weeks, expect more terrible news.
Last week, the government said the unemployment rate had shot to 8.1 percent in February.
Some 12.5 million Americans are looking for work.
Millions more fear that their next paycheck could be their last for a long while.
These figures are also undermining consumer confidence.
Although home prices and interest rates are going down, many Americans are too skittish to buy homes.
NPR's senior business editor Marilyn Geewax is here to sort out the data.
Welcome to the program.
Hey, thank you very much.
What do you think, have these awful numbers, have they hit bottom or are there any indications that the job market will improve anytime soon?
We have no silver linings.
At this point, things really look terrible.
We're in just a freefalling labor market.
And, to me, the most disturbing number that I saw last week was not really the Labor Department report on unemployment - we knew that was going to be bad.
What frightened me more was the report that came out on Thursday that had to do with productivity.
Productivity is a measure of how much a worker puts out in an hour.
So we like to have good productivity.
We like to see people busy.
Those numbers were plummeting.
In the fourth quarter of 2008, we just had a drop off the cliff for productivity.
Elaborate a little bit on the relationship between productivity growth and jobs.
What does one have to do with the other?

Well, if you think about what productivity is - that is the output per hour per worker - you want to have lots of orders coming in, you want your workers busy, you want them cranking out all those widgets every hour.
Well, if they're not doing that, what are they doing?
That means orders have fallen off.
A lot of employers hate to lose their workers because when business picks back up you don't want to have to retrain a new workforce.

So what we're seeing here is orders are dropping so quickly and there's so little work to do, that some workers are standing around oiling machines, restocking the shelves, sweeping the floor, just killing time praying that a new order comes in, but it's not coming.
So, what we're really seeing is that this drop in productivity means at some point the employers are going to cry uncle and start firing more people in large numbers.
And, really, that's what happened in the fourth quarter.
We saw this drop in productivity and now we're losing the workers.
So, I would imagine that this means high school and college graduates, the prospects for them are not very promising.
This is the one good reason to celebrate being, shall we say, a little older.
I'm happy to say that I am not just out of college or out of high school because this spring is going to be brutal.
Here's what's happening is baby boomers like me are looking at their 401Ks and saying, oh my god, I have to work longer.
I'm not going to be able to retire in my 50s, early 60s.
I'm going to have to keep going for a long time.
So, I'm not clearing out of my job to make room for younger people coming behind me.
Here we are in a terrible economy, you want to have workers to retire to create new openings for young workers, but the falling stock market is making that impossible.
So, we're going to have almost a generational war with young people sitting around saying I need a job, and older workers saying if I've got a place, I am not leaving it.
I need to make up for those losses in the stock market.
NPR's senior business editor Marilyn Geewax.
Thanks a lot.
Thank you.
The mood surrounding next week's Middle East Peace Conference in Annapolis improved a bit on Friday.
Saudi Arabia finally said it will send its foreign minister to the talks.
Saudi's support of the U.S.-sponsored talks is seen as critical to any effort to end the conflict between Palestinians and Israelis, but the success of the talks is still far from guaranteed.
We're joined in the studio now by Dan Kurtzer who is the U.S.
ambassador to Israel in President Bush's first administration.

He's now a visiting professor at Princeton University and co-author of the book, ""Negotiating Arab-Israeli Peace: American Leadership in the Middle East."" Ambassador, thanks very much for being with us.
Thanks, Scott.
It's good to be here.
And, first, I think we have to ask the question of the day: Is Lebanon in any position to participate in these talks?
Probably not.
They're in the midst of their own internal crisis.
They certainly will have gotten an invitation, but I doubt very much that anybody will think seriously that they're going to participate.
Mm.
And what's the significance of the Saudis saying they're going to send someone?
There is an overabundance of natural gas in the United States today that's driving down electricity costs, making renewable energy harder and harder to compete.
And, as a result, without that premium, it becomes very difficult in terms of cost to be able to continue to operate.
(As Elena Fisher) You know, it's probably too long and full of typos, but that's what editors are for, right?
I thought, `Well, this is serious and I'm getting out of here,' so--I don't even remember jumping up and running to the exit.
I just knew that within a matter of seconds I was there.
And I saw that the flight attendant was already opening the door and that the slide was being deployed.
The pilot came over the intercom and he said, `The worst is over' and that `We're safe now.
Everybody remain calm.
So I believed him, and I went back to get my backpack, because it had my passport in it.
Mm-hmm.
So I went back and got my backpack and ran back to the exit, and I went down the slide.

And only at that moment did I realize that the plane had actually crashed, because up until then I thought that maybe we just came to a very sudden stop and that there was something wrong, and that I had even imagined the flames.
So we just had to run up this hill and we ran all the way to the highway and I never looked back until we were in the safety of the coach, and then I realized, really, what could have happened.
Mm-hmm.
Were you seated in an aisle or a middle seat?
I was actually on the left side, right at the window, at the rear of the plane, so I was one of the first to evacuate.
Uh-huh, because there was a door nearby?
Exactly.
And people have talked about the--just how good the flight attendants were.
They were amazing.
I 100 percent believe that the only reason all of us evacuated is because of the crew and because of the police response.

By the time I got up to the highway--it must have only been three minutes that it took for me to run from the plane to the highway--there were already fire trucks spraying on the fire, and I knew that it was because of the crew and the police officers that were already there, and the fire officers, that that's why we all survived.
How did the other passengers react?
I mean, if you were at a window seat, there must have been a couple of people between you and the aisle.
It's true.
There was one man next to me.
He was an absolute angel and--because I was by myself on the plane.
I was flying home after a month in Europe by myself, and I was just kind of ready to go home.
Mm-hmm.
And when we had to escape, he held my hand the whole time and we ran through everything together, just to make sure that, you know, each other were safe.
But I didn't feel a lot of panic while I was on the plane.
Everybody--I didn't even feel scared and I don't think many other people felt scared, because you just--you couldn't even think.
You just knew that you had to get out of there and that was your number-one priority.
You mentioned going down the slide, the inflatable slide.
Some of them didn't work.
What about yours?
Mine worked, thankfully.

I think--I'm not sure, exactly, but I think there was only one exit that was working, and I was basically--I was on the left side of the plane across from the exit, so I only had to walk down a couple seats and over to the right side of the plane and I was out.
I was very lucky.
And the lights went out, you said, but there are supposed to be emergency lights.
Did those work?
There were hazard--I think they were hazard lights.
They were orange.
Uh-huh.
They came on.
But, again, that is just so--it's like a montage in my head.
I just see these images of us bumping and the oxygen masks and then the flames, so you just--you're in this mode that you have to get out of there as quickly as possible.
I didn't even realize--like, I didn't take note that any of the overhead compartments were opening or anything like that.
Mm-hmm.
When you finally got to the ground, was there somebody there to say, `Keep running, keep going this way'?
Yeah.
We were directed up the hill, and I have no idea who it was that directed us up the hill, just because I didn't think to look at their name tag or anything.
I just followed the mass.
And then we were ushered into an empty transport truck.
Mm-hmm.
And we all stayed there for a long time, but we were very close to the wreck at this point.
We were all pretty nervous because I guess they needed police clearance to drive us off.
